case_name: Hans Muller v. West Bengal Government

facts.text: Petitioner Hans Muller was arrested by the Calcutta Police on the 18th September 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, Hans Muller, who is number a citizen of India, and who is said to be a West German subject, was arrested by the Calcutta Police on the 18th September, 1954 and was placed under preventive detention.

facts.text: Hans Muller was placed under preventive detention by the West Bengal Government under section 3(1) of the Preventive Detention Act of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, Hans Muller, who is number a citizen of India, and who is said to be a West German subject, was arrested by the Calcutta Police on the 18th September, 1954 and was placed under preventive detention. The order was made by the West Bengal Government under section 3 1  of the Preventive Detention Act of 1950  Act IV of 1950  on the ground that his detention was with a view to making arrangements for his explusion from India.

facts.text: Grounds of detention were served on Hans Muller on the 22nd of September 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds were served on the 22nd of September, 1954. The second ground runs- That you are a foreigner within the meaning of the Foreigners Act, 1946  Act XXXI of 1946  and that it has become necessary to make arrangements for your expulsion from India and for this purpose you are required to be detained under section 3  1   b  of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950 until the issue of an appropriate order of expulsion from the Central Government.

facts.text: The second ground of detention stated that Hans Muller is a foreigner within the meaning of the Foreigners Act 1946 and detention necessary for arrangements for expulsion from India.

anchor.surface_text: The second ground runs- That you are a foreigner within the meaning of the Foreigners Act, 1946  Act XXXI of 1946  and that it has become necessary to make arrangements for your expulsion from India and for this purpose you are required to be detained under section 3  1   b  of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950 until the issue of an appropriate order of expulsion from the Central Government.

facts.text: On 19th September 1954, Hans Muller wrote to the Consul-General of West Germany at Calcutta about his arrest and requesting an early interview.

anchor.surface_text: On the day after his arrest, namely on the 19th of September, 1954 he wrote to the Consul-General of West Germany at Calcutta saying that be had been arrested and- asking for an early interview. This was granted.

facts.text: Interview with West German Consul was granted to Hans Muller.

anchor.surface_text: This was granted.

facts.text: On 21st September 1954, petitioner wrote to West Bengal Government requesting immediate repatriation from India.

anchor.surface_text: On the 21st of September 1954, the petitioner wrote to the West Bengal Government asking it to be kind enough to pass an order for our immediate repatriation from India 1287 and to do the necessary arrangement for our transmission out of India.

facts.text: On 9th October 1954, Calcutta Police handed petitioner's passport to West German Consul at Consul's request.

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th of October 1954 the Calcutta Police handed the petitioners passport over to the West German Consul at the Consuls request. This passport was issued to the petitioner by the West German Government at Nurenburg in West Germany on the 27th of November 1953.

facts.text: Passport issued to Hans Muller by West German Government at Nuremberg on 27th November 1953.

anchor.surface_text: This passport was issued to the petitioner by the West German Government at Nurenburg in West Germany on the 27th of November 1953. When the passport was handed over to the West German Consul it had on it a number of visas, including an Indian, all of which had on them the companydition while the passport is valid.

facts.text: West German Consul made entry on passport: Valid only for return voyage to Federal Republic of Germany until 8th January 1955.

anchor.surface_text: When the West German Consul got the passport he made the following entry on it Valid only for the return voyage to the Federal Republic of Germany until the 8th January 1955. The petitioner companyplains that this invalidated all the other visas and as, according to this fresh entry, the passport ceased to be valid after the 8th of January 1955, he number has numberpassport.

facts.text: On 9th October 1954, West German Government wrote to West Bengal Government about arrest warrant against petitioner in West Germany for frauds, pending proceedings, charges in Lebanon and Egypt, request for provisional warrant for detention till extradition, arranged repatriation on boat KANDELfels arriving 19th October.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, the 9th of October 1954, the West German Government wrote to the West Bengal Government saying that a warrant of arrest was issued against the petitioner in West Germany in companynection with a number of frauds and that legal proceedings in companynection with those warrants are still pending. The Consul also said that he had received information that similar charges had been made against the petitioner in Lebanon and in Egypt and be companycluded- The Government of the Federal Republic of Germany will apply for Mullers extradition through diplomatic channels whilst at the same time submitting the supporting documents.

facts.text: Secretary to West Bengal Government noted: no objection to keeping Muller in detention till 19th instant, issue order of release when boat ready to sail.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this letter the Secretary to the Government of West Bengal recorded the following numbere I suppose there would be numberobjection to our keeping Muller in detention till the 19th instant. We must issue order of his release as soon as his boat is ready to sail.

facts.text: West Bengal Government had no power to deport the petitioner; only Central Government could.

anchor.surface_text: The West Bengal Government had numberpower to deport the petitioner. Only the Central Government companyld do that, and up till the 20th of October the Central Government had number passed any orders.

facts.text: Up till 20th October 1954, Central Government had not passed any orders for expulsion.

anchor.surface_text: Only the Central Government companyld do that, and up till the 20th of October the Central Government had number passed any orders.

facts.text: On 20th October 1954, petitioner applied to High Court of Calcutta for writ of habeas corpus under section 491 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: On that date the petitioner applied to the High Court of Calcutta for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus under section 491 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: High Court of Calcutta dismissed the habeas corpus petition on 10-12-1954.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court decided against the petitioner on all points and dismissed the petition on 10-12-1954.

facts.text: Present petition filed in Supreme Court on 10-1-1955 under Article 32.

anchor.surface_text: He thereupon made the present petition to this Court on the same grounds, presumably under article 32 of the Constitution. It was filed oil 10-1-1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on 1955 February 23 by BOSE J.

anchor.surface_text: 1955. February 23. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.-The petitioner, Hans Muller, who is number a citizen of India, and who is said to be a West German subject, was arrested by the Calcutta Police on the 18th September, 1954 and was placed under preventive detention.

facts.text: Central Government has made and signed expulsion orders but holding in abeyance pending SC decision.

anchor.surface_text: Because of that, and because this matter has been pending in the companyrts ever since, numberorders have yet been issued for his expulsion from India though we are told by the learned Attorney-General that they have been made and signed but are being held in abeyance pending the decision of this petition.

facts.text: Petitioner contended detention invalid because s.3(1)(b) ultra vires Constitution on grounds contravening arts 21,22,14; not preventive detention; bad faith.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner companytended that his detention was invalid for the following, among other, reasons Because section 3 1  b  of the Preventive Detention Act, the section under which the order was. made, is ultra vires the Constitution on three grounds-  a  that it companytravenes articles 21 and 22  b  that it companytravenes article 14, and  c  that it was beyond the legislative companypetence of Parliament to enact such a law Because section 3 1   b  is number a law of preventive detention within the meaning of article 22 3  and therefore it companytravenes article 22  1  and  2  and Because, in any event, the order was made in bad faith.

facts.text: Detention order made by State Government, not Centre.

anchor.surface_text: The detention order is by a State Government and number by the Centre.

facts.text: West German Consul requested provisional warrant to ensure detention up to extradition; expenses for repatriation borne by West German Government.

anchor.surface_text: As this will require a certain amount of time, I am directed to give you advance information of this step and hereby request the Government of West Bengal to issue a provisional warrant of arrest which ensures Mullers detention up to the date of his extradition to Germany. This Consulate has already arranged for Mullers repatriation by the German boat KANDELFELS due to arrive in Calcutta on the 19th instant. All 1288 expenses in companynection with Mullers repatriation will be borne by the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany.

facts.text: German boat KANDELfels due to arrive in Calcutta on 19th October 1954.

anchor.surface_text: This Consulate has already arranged for Mullers repatriation by the German boat KANDELFELS due to arrive in Calcutta on the 19th instant.

facts.text: Petition No. 22 of 1955 in Original Jurisdiction under Article 32 for habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 22 of 1955. Under Article 32 of the Constitution for a Writ in the nature of habeas companypus.
Under Article 32 of the Constitution for a Writ in the nature of habeas companypus.
On that date the petitioner applied to the High Court of Calcutta for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus under section 491 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.text: The competence of the Central Legislature to enact a law dealing with this aspect of preventive detention is derived from Entry 9 of the Union List read with Entry 10

anchor.surface_text: The competence of the Central Legislature to enact a law dealing with this aspect of preventive detention is derived from Entry 9 of the Union List read with Entry 10, The portion of Entry 9 which concerns us is as follows Preventive detention for reasons connected with Foreign Affairs

holdings.reasoning_summary: Widest scope to entries as machinery of government; detention of foreigners and expulsion relates to foreign affairs bringing Union into relation with foreign countries

holdings.text: the limitations imposed on this power by articles 21 and 22 have been observed

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the limitations imposed on this power by articles 21 and 22 have been observed. Article 21 guarantees the protection of personal liberty to citizen and foreigner alike.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preventive Detention Act framed with Arts 21 and 22 limitations in view; procedure like production before magistrate and grounds served complied with

holdings.text: Detention in such circumstances is rightly termed preventive and falls within the ambit of the Preventive Detention Act and is reasonably related to the purpose of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Detention in such circumstances is rightly termed preventive and falls within the ambit of the Preventive Detention Act and is reasonably related to the purpose of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ancillary to expulsion right under Foreigners Act; prevents breach by detention until arrangements made; reasonable when criminal charges exist

holdings.text: The Preventive Detention Act expressly confers the right to detain with a view to making arrangements for the expulsion upon both the State and the Central Government

anchor.surface_text: The Preventive Detention Act expressly confers the right to detain -with a view to making, arrangements for the expulsion upon both the State and the Central Government and the satisfaction required by section 3 1 b can be of either Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State satisfaction expressly allowed; necessary for timely action before Central expulsion order to avoid evasion

holdings.text: the classification of foreigners into those who are British subjects of the kind set out in the definition, and others, so as to make the former not foreigners for the purposes of the Foreigners Act and the Preventive Detention Act, is a reasonable and rational classification and so does not, on the authority of our previous decisions, offend article 14

anchor.surface_text: The classification of foreigners into those who are British subjects of the kind set out in the definition, and others, so as to make the former not foreigners for the purposes of the Foreigners Act and the Preventive Detention Act, is a reasonable and rational classification and so does not, on the authority of our previous decisions, offend article 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification rule repeatedly applied; reasons of State justify grouping foreigners differently

holdings.text: even if it be true that there is the discrimination alleged, namely between one class of British subject and another, that will not give the petitioner a right of challenge on this ground. He is not a British subject

anchor.surface_text: We do not intend to examine this contention because, even if it be true that there is the discrimination alleged, namely between one class of British subject and another, that will not give the petitioner a right of challenge on this ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Only aggrieved persons can challenge under Art 32; petitioner not British subject so lacks standing

holdings.text: We hold that the impugned portions of section 3 1 b of the Preventive Detention Act and section 3 2 c of the Foreigners Act, 1946 are intra vires

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the impugned portions of section 3 1 b of the Preventive Detention Act and section 3 2 c of the Foreigners Act, 1946 are intra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Covers legislative competence, Arts 14,21,22 challenges; all rejected

holdings.text: We see no force in the first part of the petitioners argument... This line of attack on the good faith of Government falls to the ground

anchor.surface_text: We see no force in the first part of the petitioners argument. We are at bottom considering the question of the West Bengal Governments good faith. The order of detention was made before the West German Consul wrote his letter

holdings.reasoning_summary: No material showing change of purpose post-consul letter; secretary note not indicative of government mind

holdings.text: Our conclusion is that the Foreigners Act is not governed by the provisions of the Extradition Act. The two are distinct and neither impinges on the other

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion is that the Foreigners Act is not governed by the provisions of the Extradition Act. The two are distinct and neither impinges on the other.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate constitutional entries; unfettered discretion to expel without extradition formalities; expelled leaves as free man unlike extradition

holdings.text: Government is given the right to choose [expulsion over extradition], no question of want of good faith can arise merely because it exercises the right of choice which the law confers

anchor.surface_text: If no choice had been left to the Government, the position would have been different but as Government is given the right to choose, no question of want of good faith can arise merely because it exercises the right of choice which the law confers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absolute discretion under Foreigners Act; request for extradition does not bind government to follow that procedure

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the impugned portions of section 3 1 b of the Preventive Detention Act and section 3 2 c of the Foreigners Act, 1946 are intra vires. We now turn to a wider question that brings us to the fringe of International law.

outcome.relief_summary: Writ petition dismissed; section 3(1)(b) of Preventive Detention Act held intra vires; detention held valid; good faith of government upheld; no merit in petitioner's grounds
